awd_titl_txt: CRII: III: Computational framework for disparate data integration  to study cancer drug resistance
awd_abstract_narration:
With the advent of high-throughput biotechnology, people can now investigate a biological system with multiple bioassays using diverse types of study objects. The convolution of multiple bioassays, study objects and exposure conditions produces a wealth of rich information about the biological system, and at the same time, poses great challenge on how to integrate heterogeneous data sources and extract sufficient knowledge that cannot be gained from any single dataset alone. Depending on the complexity level of the convolution, direct data integration is often used when combing information from multiple bioassays on a cohort of similar study objects, and indirect integration via knowledge transfer is generally attractive when it comes to the power of incorporating relatively more diverse data types. Direct information integration relies on concordant and well annotated data structures, and the connections between datasets are usually easily understood. These methodologies have to meet many computational challenges owing to different sizes, formats and dimensionalities of the data being integrated. In biological studies, researchers tend to study their system using models varying in terms of species (human vs. mouse), compositions (tissue vs. cell lines, single cells) and/or exposures conditions. Thus, the datasets generated are drawn from different feature space and/or different sample distributions, where direct integration becomes infeasible. These highly disparate datasets may each have the potential to provide complimentary information key to the research question being carried out, and thus it is also urgent to construct a transfer learning method tailored for high-throughput bioassay data so that existing heterogeneous datasets could be re-purposed in a future study.

To address these challenges, this project will develop new classes of computational methods for direct information integration and indirect knowledge transfer, and ultimately leverage structures and relations among various bioassay datasets for better understanding of a biological system, for example, cancer drug resistance mechanism. The research team will achieve their goals through exerting the following two objectives. First, they will develop a novel formulation for information distillation on multiple -omics data so that knowledge could be easily transplantable to future studies, which would otherwise be prevented due to technical and platform bias. The framework consists of a supervised sparse clustering method for qualitative representation of coherent signatures, together with a co-clustering approach to detect local low rank structures. Second, they will develop a novel transfer learning method by imposing the structural regularities learnt from the source domains to any target domain. The key assumption is that the structural regularities are invariant to technical and platform bias, so they are ideal vehicle for knowledge transfer. The project is expected to develop novel computational tools that can effectively explore a wide range of heterogeneous datasets, and it has great potential to minimize the cost on recollecting new training data, by maximizing utilization of existing information and fully using the knowledge derived therefrom to substantiate our understanding of a biological/biomedical system. Hence the project will have far-reaching economic and societal impacts.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Research:

For this project, I proposed to develop new classes of computational methods for integration of heterogeneously sourced data by mining and transfer of the latent structures in the datasets. To extract these locally coherent patterns, I developed submatrix identification algorithm for real-valued matrix, Boolean matrix, and all-way Boolean tensor. A computational pipeline for extracting the local patterns that are particularly applied to study cancer drug resistance was also developed. My research results have been disseminated to the communities of interest through publication, preprints, abstracts and presentations. Altogether, I published 11 peer-reviewed papers, and I have ten more papers that are currently under review or close to be submitted. I have been invited to present these work to interested communities, including externally at nine major universities, and four international conferences. Our developed computational methods and tools can effectively explore a wide range of heterogeneous and even outdated biomedical datasets, identify experimentally unrevealed relations among them, and fully utilize the knowledge derived therefrom to substantiate our understanding of a target biological systems. Our proposed methodologies adopt a highly data driven approach and maximally consider all available data in a systematical manner. In particular, the biomedical data often has much larger number of features than samples, our algorithms always specifically address the feature selection challenge. Thus, they have a high potential to discover new knowledge and to induce new approaches that could be significant to bioinformatics research. 

 

Education:

Since 2019 Spring, I have been developing a novel course on ?Topics of statistical learning and high dimensional data analysis?. I developed this course from scratch, and taught it in 2019 Spring. Since then, I have been refining this course by including more state of the art knowledge inspired by my independent research. In 2021 Fall, I taught this course again with my colleague, and we managed to put all the lecture recordings on YouTube to benefit broader range of audience (https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCJsV8jYuH5bGOlqSnaAoOxA/featured). This has targeted students from Bioinformatics, Biostatistics and Computer Science, which aims to address the significant curriculum gap in data analytics for biomedical problems.

In the summer of 2021, together with three other colleagues, I organized a health data science workshop, which has 14 sessions in total, each lasting for an hour. During the summer workshop, on average 40 high school and undergraduate students attended, in addition to five high school teachers. The students were participants of various summer educational programs at the Indiana University, including the STEM/SEED (Summer Experience for the Economically Disadvantaged) project, IU Simon Cancer Center Summer Research Program (IUSCC-SRP) and Future Scientist Program (FSP). The workshop covered topics on R/Python programming, data visualization, basic statistics, and computational biology. All the learning materials have been deposited in our GitHub portal (https://github.com/zcslab/2021_Summer_STEM_workshop), for the use of other general audience.

I hosted two high school students in 2020, six high school students and one undergraduate interns in 2021, and seven high school students in 2022, to work as research interns in my group. The students were all recruited from the IUSM STEM/SEED and FSP programs. The interns were all involved in hands-on experience in constructing a data hub. Basically, the students were expected to write simple script language for data pulling, pre-processing, annotation, analysis, and results interpretation. All students presented a poster by the end of the internship to their respective program, and their works were spoken highly of. The data hub was meant to facilitate interdisciplinary disciplines between biomedical science and data science, where the data scientists could strive to develop algorithms that are particularly applicable to challenges in the biomedical data. This will be a long-term project, as we expect new biomedical datasets generated by new biotechnology grow each year. Notably, under my mentorship, six high school students wrote and submitted a manuscript to Frontiers in Oncology, and as of December 2022, we were invited to revise the manuscript for minor comments. 

My educational activities, including novel graduate level course development, summer internship, and summer data science workshop, can well serve as a platform for training students into the future STEM workforce with data mining skills in interdisciplinary field, and thus has significant educational impacts. All the related materials are accessible from our github portal, to benefit other interested students in the community. The proposed project converted the new discoveries, along with the state-of-the-art knowledge, into educational material, which has enriched the graduate course syllabus and the workshop materials that the PI has been developing. This has provided students from various backgrounds an excellent channel to be exposed to the rapidly developing biotech industry and multidisciplinary field of bioinformatics. Ultimately, the project will contribute to training a new generation of scientists with the capacity of computational and bioinformatics technologies prepared for solving challenging biomedical questions.
